questions.text: All among the following are ionizing radiations except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ionizing Radiation

questions.text: The following scan is of a young woman on oral contraceptives. The most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hepatic adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors often associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). They occur more frequently in young women and are known for their risk of hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. RML consolidation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The X-ray shown above indicates consolidation due to presence of opacities in the right middle lobe silhouetting the right heart border along with the history of fever, cough and hemoptysis.
  • • Silhouette sign
  • • Silhouette sign
  • • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localized to middle lobe /lingula When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localized to lower lobe.
  • • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localized to middle lobe /lingula
  • • When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localized to lower lobe.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. RLL consolidation: Typically presents with obscuration of the right hemidiaphragm on X-ray, not the heart border.
  • • Option B. RLL consolidation:
  • • Option C. RUL consolidation: Would more commonly show opacities in the upper right lung without affecting the silhouette of the heart.
  • • Option C. RUL consolidation:
  • • Option D. Pericardial effusion: Would generally show an enlarged cardiac silhouette ("water bottle" sign), which is not evident in this image.
  • • Option D. Pericardial effusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ RML consolidation can be diagnosed when there is obscuration of the right heart border due to lung opacities in the middle lobe, accompanied by clinical symptoms of respiratory infection.

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty and a whole-body CT scan has to be done. This CT scan will include the following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. CT Limbs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A whole-body CT scan for trauma includes NCCT of the head and C-spine, and CECT of the chest and abdomen, while limb injuries are typically evaluated through physical examination and imaged only when necessary.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with a history of cholelithiasis, presented with vomiting and abdominal pain. The abdominal radiograph showed Rigler's triad. Which of these is not a component of Rigler's triad? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Large bowel obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rigler triad consists of three findings seen in gallstone ileus:
  • ➤ Rigler triad consists of three findings seen in gallstone ileus:
  • ➤ Pneumobilia Small Bowel Obstruction Ectopic calcified gallstone , usually in the right iliac fossa
  • ➤ Pneumobilia
  • ➤ Small Bowel Obstruction
  • ➤ Ectopic calcified gallstone , usually in the right iliac fossa

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests: (AIIMS 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Positive FAST

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ultrasound image shows an anechoic area (appearing dark on ultrasound), which is fluid between the liver and kidney. This finding is indicative of a hemoperitoneum, suggesting that the FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) scan is positive. A positive FAST scan in this context typically points to the presence of free fluid in the abdomen, which in trauma settings, is usually due to bleeding, confirming a hemoperitoneum.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Negative FAST: This would imply no visible free fluid; the image, however, shows clear evidence of fluid.
  • • Option A. Negative FAST:
  • • Option C. Equivocal FAST: This term would be used if the findings were unclear or uncertain, which is not the case here as the fluid is distinctly visible.
  • • Option C. Equivocal FAST:
  • • Option D. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the abdominal cavity and would present differently on an ultrasound, typically as increased echogenicity reflecting off the free air; this is not visible in the provided image.
  • • Option D. Pneumoperitoneum:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anechoic fluid between liver and kidney is suggestive of hemoperitoneum-FAST positive
  • ➤ Anechoic fluid between liver and kidney is suggestive of hemoperitoneum-FAST positive
  • ➤ eFAST: Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma
  • ➤ eFAST:
  • ➤ Focus:
  • ➤ Focus:
  • ➤ Hemoperitoneum (free fluid in abdomen) Pericardial effusion Pneumothorax Hemothorax
  • ➤ Hemoperitoneum (free fluid in abdomen)
  • ➤ Pericardial effusion
  • ➤ Pneumothorax
  • ➤ Hemothorax

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps with persistent low mood. Which of the following would be the best investigation for a definitive diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with bone pain and abdominal cramps along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.
  • • IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While useful for detailed soft tissue imaging, MRI is not the first choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.
  • • Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging):
  • • Option C. Ultrasonogram: Can be used to locate parathyroid adenomas but has limitations in sensitivity and specificity compared to the Sestamibi scan.
  • • Option C. Ultrasonogram:
  • • Option D. CT scan (Computed Tomography): Provides good anatomic detail but is less specific than the Sestamibi scan for parathyroid adenomas and is not the primary diagnostic tool for suspected hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Option D. CT scan (Computed Tomography):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a definitive diagnosis in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of hypercalcemia and suspected primary hyperparathyroidism, a Sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice due to its specificity and ability to perform detailed scintigraphic imaging.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phrygian cap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Phrygian cap is the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder, appearing as a fold at the gallbladder fundus. It is asymptomatic and has no pathological significance, important to recognize in imaging to differentiate it from potential abnormalities.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cephalhematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cephalhematoma is a localized hematoma under the periosteum of the skull bone in newborns, confined by suture lines and typically associated with birth trauma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with low back ache for 20 days. CE-MRI is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pott’s spine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pott's spine should be considered in patients presenting with back pain and MRI findings of disc destruction and epidural abscess, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is common.

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest X-ray, the following object is seen. Identify? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Button battery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image you’ve provided shows a radiopaque object in the esophagus of a child, which is identified as a button battery.
  • • On X-rays, button batteries typically present as small, circular objects with a double rim or halo effect. This is because they have a distinctive two-layer structure which shows up clearly on radiographs. The appearance in the X-ray is characteristic of a button battery, with a clearly visible double rim. This is a medical emergency due to the risk of rapid and severe damage to the mucosal tissues from electrical discharge and leakage of caustic substances.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Coin : Coins are also circular and radiopaque on X-rays but lack the double rim feature seen with button batteries. Coins tend to be uniform in density throughout. Although they are a common type of foreign body ingested by children, they generally pose less immediate danger compared to button batteries.
  • • Option B. Coin
  • • Option C. Ball : A small ball, depending on its material, might appear on an X-ray if it's dense enough. However, it would not typically show the structured double rim characteristic of a button battery.
  • • Option C. Ball
  • • Option D. Bottle Cap : Bottle caps may appear circular but would show irregular edges or threading and do not have the double rim appearance.
  • • Option D. Bottle Cap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate identification and removal of an ingested button battery are crucial due to the rapid damage that can occur. Emergency endoscopic retrieval is usually necessary to prevent severe injury or death.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is conscious, BP is 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Needle thoracostomy

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance .
  • • figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance
  • • TAPVC:
  • • TAPVC:
  • • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • • pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium.
  • • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • The following types are seen:
  • • The following types are seen:
  • • I. Supra cardiac – Most common type
  • • I. Supra cardiac –
  • • II. Cardiac
  • • II. Cardiac
  • • III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)
  • • III. Infra cardiac –
  • • (worst prognosis)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.
  • • Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus:
  • • Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.
  • • Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries):
  • • Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'
  • • Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: A child has been brought into the emergency department with symptoms of bilious vomiting. Below is an X-ray image of the abdomen: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "double bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray in a neonate with bilious vomiting is highly suggestive of duodenal atresia. This condition requires surgical intervention, and timely diagnosis is crucial to manage potential complications and outcomes effectively.
  • ➤ The "double bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray in a neonate with bilious vomiting is highly suggestive of duodenal atresia. This condition requires surgical intervention, and timely diagnosis is crucial to manage potential complications and outcomes effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute radiation syndrome? (AIIMS 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression

options.label: B
options.text: Bone marrow suppression appear at doses greater than 1 Gy

options.label: C
options.text: Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects

options.label: D
options.text: GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects

questions.correct_answer: A. GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)
  • ➤ Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)
  • ➤ Occurs with accidental exposure of very high dose radiation Result of nuclear accidents
  • ➤ Occurs with accidental exposure of very high dose radiation
  • ➤ Result of nuclear accidents

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle , marked A in the given coronal CT image.
  • • Pott spine
  • • having persistent hip flexion
  • • psoas abscess
  • • involving the psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: What does the following X-ray depict? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pleural effusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given X-ray depicts left-sided pleural effusion . There is opacity of the left hemithorax with a meniscus sign/ Ellis S curve . Earliest sign on CXR: Blunting of CP angle Most sensitive Xray: I/L lateral decubitus Most sensitive Investigation: USG
  • • The given X-ray depicts left-sided pleural effusion .
  • • left-sided pleural effusion
  • • There is opacity of the left hemithorax with a meniscus sign/ Ellis S curve .
  • • meniscus sign/ Ellis S curve
  • • Earliest sign on CXR: Blunting of CP angle
  • • Blunting of CP angle
  • • Most sensitive Xray: I/L lateral decubitus
  • • I/L lateral decubitus
  • • Most sensitive Investigation: USG
  • • USG
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A. Emphysema: Typically presents with hyperinflated lungs, flattened diaphragms, and decreased vascular markings on X-ray, not with opacity or a meniscus sign.
  • • Option. A. Emphysema:
  • • Option. B. Tension pneumothorax: Characterized by a collapsed lung with mediastinal shift to the opposite side and absence of lung markings, which is not seen in the provided X-ray.
  • • Option. B. Tension pneumothorax:
  • • Option. D. Bronchiectasis: Shows bronchial wall thickening and dilation, often with a "tram-track" appearance, which is not consistent with the X-ray findings of pleural effusion.
  • • Option. D. Bronchiectasis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleural effusion is identified on an X-ray by the opacity of the hemithorax and the presence of a meniscus sign, with the most sensitive investigation being ultrasound (USG).

questions.text: Ga-68 PSMA scan is useful for the diagnosis of which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prostate cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ga-68 PSMA scan is specifically designed for the diagnosis and management of prostate cancer, as it targets the Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen expressed on prostate cancer cells.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior rib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior rib appears as a horizontal structure on a chest X-ray, distinguishing it from the more curved anterior ribs and other thoracic structures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a smoking history of 36 pack years presents with numbness and weakness of the right hand and arm and tingling in the fingers. There is associated drooping of the right eye with miosis. What is the IOC for the patient? (AIIMS 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: USG Doppler of right upper limb

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation is pointing towards a diagnosis of right Pancoast or superior sulcus tumor involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus. Radiographic findings include an apical mass or unilateral or asymmetrical apical pleural thickening (“apical cap”). Asymmetry in the thickness of an apical cap exceeding 5 mm is considered suggestive. MRI is more accurate than CT in diagnosing brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus involvement, and define the relationship of the tumor to great vessels and the brachial plexus.
  • • The clinical presentation is pointing towards a diagnosis of right Pancoast or superior sulcus tumor involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus.
  • • Radiographic findings include an apical mass or unilateral or asymmetrical apical pleural thickening (“apical cap”).
  • • Asymmetry in the thickness of an apical cap exceeding 5 mm is considered suggestive.
  • • MRI is more accurate than CT in diagnosing brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus involvement, and define the relationship of the tumor to great vessels and the brachial plexus.
  • • Regional spread can cause:
  • • Tracheal obstruction Esophageal compression with dysphagia Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).
  • • Tracheal obstruction
  • • Tracheal obstruction
  • • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).
  • • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chest X-ray: While helpful for initial evaluation, it lacks the detail required to assess soft tissue involvement and the exact extent of the tumor.
  • • Option A. Chest X-ray:
  • • Option B. USG Doppler of right upper limb: Useful for vascular assessment but not suitable for visualizing intrathoracic tumors or their impact on neural structures.
  • • Option B. USG Doppler of right upper limb:
  • • Option C. HRCT: High-resolution CT can identify the presence of an apical mass but does not provide as detailed visualization of soft tissue and neurovascular involvement as MRI.
  • • Option C. HRCT:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected Pancoast tumor, MRI is preferred over other imaging modalities for its superior ability to delineate the extent of tumor involvement with the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus, critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with confusion, constipation, and persistent low mood. ALP was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with confusion, constipation, along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.
  • • IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed soft tissue images, it is not the preferred imaging modality for detecting parathyroid adenomas.
  • • Option A. MRI:
  • • Option B. FDG PET: PET scans are used in cancer imaging and are not specific for identifying parathyroid adenomas.
  • • Option B. FDG PET:
  • • Option C. CT: While CT scans can identify anatomical details and some tumors, they lack the specificity of Sestamibi scans in identifying hyperactive parathyroid tissue.
  • • Option C. CT:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Sestamibi scan is specifically useful for identifying parathyroid adenomas in patients suspected of having primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its ability to effectively localize hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive muscle weakness, particularly affecting the eyes and throat, leading to difficulty with swallowing and drooping eyelids. Imaging studies reveal a mediastinal mass. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thymoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis, presenting with symptoms like progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and drooping eyelids.

questions.text: What type of particles does a linear accelerator use? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) X rays

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Linear accelerators are crucial in modern oncology, allowing high precision in targeting tumors while sparing healthy tissue, using high-energy X rays derived from accelerated electrons.
  • ➤ Linear accelerators are crucial in modern oncology, allowing high precision in targeting tumors while sparing healthy tissue, using high-energy X rays derived from accelerated electrons.

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.
  • ➤ Subperiosteal Abscess

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3,4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pneumothorax Hemothorax Consolidation Diaphragmatic hernia
  • • Pneumothorax
  • • Hemothorax
  • • Consolidation
  • • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • • Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.
  • • Image 3:
  • • Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.
  • • Image 4:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • • Radiographs 1-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the below image? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Horse Shoe Kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Horseshoe kidney is a congenital disorder where the kidneys are connected at the lower ends and lie across the midline. It’s often asymptomatic but can be associated with complications like urinary tract infections or stones.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most radiosensitive? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Testis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The testis is highly radiosensitive due to the high rate of cell division in germ cells, making it more susceptible to radiation compared to other tissues listed.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Carcinoma Esophagus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical history of an elderly female presenting with symptoms such as progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite and weight loss along with the given barium study which shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins . These findings are suggestive of Carcinoma Esophagus.
  • • barium study which shows irregular narrowing,
  • • mucosal destruction and shouldered margins
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Is a motility disorder of esophagus and appears as a corkscrew esophagus .
  • • Option A.
  • • Diffuse esophageal spasm:
  • • motility disorder of esophagus
  • • corkscrew esophagus
  • • Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma: Is a benign neoplasm of the esophagus and on barium swallow it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.
  • • Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma:
  • • benign neoplasm of the esophagus
  • • discrete ovoid mass
  • • Option D. Esophageal webs: Refers to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen .
  • • Option D. Esophageal webs:
  • • esophageal constriction
  • • thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an elderly patient presenting with progressive dysphagia for solids and significant weight loss, the presence of irregular narrowing and shouldered margins on a barium swallow is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. Diagnostic confirmation typically requires upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and biopsy. For tumor staging, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is used for T and N staging, while PET-CT is utilized for M staging.

questions.text: Identify the image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Metastasis to breast from another primary site

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Fibroadenoma appearance on USG is as a ‘Halo’ sign.

questions.text: 74-year-old man presents with history of significant weight loss, and loss of appetite. There is no associated cough or hemoptysis. Chest X-ray was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Metastasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple round opacities on a chest X-ray in a patient with significant systemic symptoms such as weight loss should prompt consideration of metastatic disease. Further diagnostic investigations, including a CT scan of the chest and biopsy, are recommended to confirm the origin and nature of the nodules.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the OPD with a large mass in the lower back. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Meningocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meningocele is indicated by a T2 hyperintense mass on MRI showing fluid herniation from the spine and presents as a fluctuant midline mass with positive transillumination.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given X-ray finding seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Reflux esophagitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appearance of a feline esophagus on a barium swallow X-ray is indicative of eosinophilic esophagitis and is often associated with conditions like asthma and GERD. This finding underscores the importance of considering inflammatory and allergic contributions in patients presenting with esophageal symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Typical carcinoids generally do not show avid uptake on an FDG PET scan because they are well-differentiated tumors with relatively low metabolic activity compared to more aggressive cancers. FDG PET scans are most effective in identifying tumors that have high glucose metabolism, which is more characteristic of rapidly growing and less differentiated tumors. Typical carcinoids, being slow-growing, often exhibit minimal FDG uptake, making them less detectable on PET scans.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Small cell carcinoma : This type of cancer is highly aggressive and shows high metabolic activity, making it usually very avid on FDG PET scans.
  • • Option B. Small cell carcinoma
  • • Option C. Atypical carcinoid: More aggressive than typical carcinoids, often showing intermediate to high FDG uptake due to higher metabolic activity.
  • • Option C. Atypical carcinoid:
  • • Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma : A highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that generally shows significant FDG uptake due to its rapid growth and high metabolic rate.
  • • Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:
  • ➤ Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:
  • ➤ Lung adenocarcinoma
  • ➤ Mucinous adenocarcinoma
  • ➤ Typical carcinoid

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.
  • • Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase
  • • Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): Features ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies, often with a "candle wax dripping" appearance, distinct from the findings in alkaptonuria.
  • • Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis):
  • • Option B. Fluorosis: Typically presents with increased bone density and ossification of interosseous ligaments, not specifically associated with hyperpigmentation or the disc calcifications shown.
  • • Option B. Fluorosis:
  • • Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Characterized by a "bamboo spine" appearance due to bony fusion, seen in younger patients (less than 50 years old), which does not typically include hyperpigmentation or the type of disc calcification seen in alkaptonuria.
  • • Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase
  • ➤ Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification
  • ➤ DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis
  • ➤ DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding of large bowel obstruction? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Dilated loops with haustrations

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dilated bowel loops with haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction.
  • • Large bowel obstructions have colonic distension proximal to the obstruction with the distal portion collapsed. The colon is considered dilated if it is more than 6 cm in diameter while the cut off for caecum is 9cm.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes: Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circulars (valvulae conniventes) and predominantly central loops are features of the small bowel obstruction. The small bowel is considered dilated if it is more than 3 cm in diameter.
  • • Option A. Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes:
  • • Option B. String of pearls sign: The string of pearls sign is also a feature of small bowel obstruction seen in plain radiographs or CT. It represents a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes.
  • • Option B. String of pearls sign:
  • • Option C. Central dilated bowel loops: While central dilation can occur in any intestinal obstruction, it is more typical of small bowel obstruction where the loops tend to centrally accumulate.
  • • Option C. Central dilated bowel loops:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identifying dilated loops with haustrations is critical for diagnosing large bowel obstruction, helping differentiate it from small bowel obstruction, which features dilated loops with valvulae conniventes and may show the string of pearls sign.

questions.text: Identify the hemorrhage shown in the given image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subdural hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subdural hemorrhages, typically appear as crescent-shaped hyperdense areas on CT scans and in particular, require timely intervention to manage increased intracranial pressure and prevent permanent damage or death. They can present with symptoms ranging from mild headaches to severe neurological deficits, depending on the extent of the bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions Hamman’s sign can be appreciated? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pneumomediastinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamman's sign, a crunching or crackling sound with each heartbeat, is associated with pneumomediastinum caused by the entry of air into the mediastinum.

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign on MRI is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Arachnoiditis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The empty thecal sac sign, which appears on MRI as an apparent absence or clumping of the nerve roots within the thecal sac, is indicative of arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis is an inflammation of the arachnoid linings of the spinal canal, which can cause the nerve roots to clump together and adhere to one another or the lining of the canal, leaving the thecal sac appearing empty or devoid of its normal content of floating nerve roots.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Discitis: An inflammation of the intervertebral disc, which would not typically show the empty thecal sac sign but might show disc space narrowing and endplate erosions.
  • • Option B. Discitis:
  • • Option C. Vertebral osteomyelitis: An infection of the vertebral bodies, generally presenting with bony destruction, soft tissue swelling, and possibly an abscess but not the empty thecal sac sign.
  • • Option C. Vertebral osteomyelitis:
  • • Option D. Tethered cord syndrome: Characterized by an abnormally low conus medullaris with associated thickened filum terminale, not typically associated with the empty thecal sac sign.
  • • Option D. Tethered cord syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI of Arachnoiditis shows Empty thecal sac sign.
  • ➤ Due to inflammation, nerve roots are clumped and empty thecal sac are seen on MRI of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hiatal hernia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Retrocardiac air fluid level is seen on CXR which is suggestive of a hiatal hernia. It is defined as the displacement through esophageal hiatus of GE junction or other parts of the stomach into the thoracic cavity
  • • IOC for hiatal hernia: Contrast enhanced CT + oral contrast (Iohexol most commonly) (to determine obstruction/ Volvulus)
  • • IOC for hiatal hernia:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Bochdalek hernia: This is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia typically occurring at the posterolateral part of the diaphragm, not associated with the retrocardiac region.
  • • Option A. Bochdalek hernia:
  • • Option B. Morgagni hernia: Another type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs anteriorly at the sternocostal triangles, not retrocardiac.
  • • Option B. Morgagni hernia:
  • • Option D. Eventration of diaphragm: Involves an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm muscle, not typically presenting as an air-fluid level in the retrocardiac area.
  • • Option D. Eventration of diaphragm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hiatal hernia can be diagnosed on plain chest X-ray when an air-fluid level is visible in the retrocardiac area, indicating herniation of stomach contents into the thorax through the esophageal hiatus. Contrast-enhanced CT with oral contrast is the imaging of choice for further evaluation, particularly to assess for any complications like obstruction or volvulus.

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is not used for brachytherapy?(FMGE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Iodine-131

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brachytherapy implants:
  • ➤ Brachytherapy implants:
  • ➤ Permanent implants trick: “ GIPCY ”
  • ➤ GIPCY

questions.text: 50yr old male presenting with diffuse back pain; Cervical spine Xray shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. DISH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.
  • • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH), also known as Forestier disease, is a common condition characterized by bony proliferation of the spine affecting elderly individuals. On imaging, it is typically characterized by the flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament involving the thoracic spine.
  • • There is no involvement of the sacroiliac synovial joints.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis: This condition would typically present with a "bamboo spine" appearance, resulting from fusion across the intervertebral disc spaces and sacroiliac joints, which is not evident in this X-ray.
  • • Option
  • • A. Ankylosing spondylitis: This
  • • Option C. Klippel-Feil syndrome: This syndrome involves congenital fusion of any two of the cervical vertebrae, which does not match the findings in this X-ray.
  • • Option
  • • C. Klippel-Feil syndrome:
  • • Option D. Sprengel deformity: This refers to an abnormally high scapula, a condition unrelated to the spinal changes observed in the X-ray.
  • • Option
  • • D. Sprengel deformity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DISH or Forestier's disease is recognized radiologically by its classic flowing ossification along the spine's anterior longitudinal ligament, sparing joint spaces and disc heights, often seen in individuals older than 50 years without signs of sacroiliac joint involvement.
  • ➤ DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis
  • ➤ DISH VS Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan? (INCET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Anterior ethmoidal canal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anterior ethmoidal canal is noted by the marked arrows. The anterior ethmoidal canal can be recognized by the fact that it lies below the ethmoidal air cell roof. To prevent bleeding from this vessel during sinus procedures, it is crucial to recognize that the anterior ethmoidal artery runs via this canal. Maxillary sinus is noted in this view hence suggesting anterior plane.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. The posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve pass via the ethmoid bone’s posterior ethmoid canal or foramen. Due to the fact that this image is a coronal section taken at the level of the anterior ethmoidal cells, it cannot be seen.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. The cribriform plate is a sieve-like structure between the nasal cavity and the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers. Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior ethmoidal canal is critical to identify during sinus procedures to avoid complications such as bleeding from the anterior ethmoidal artery. It is located below the roof of the ethmoidal air cells and anterior to the posterior ethmoidal canal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image below. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) UGIE + manometry

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario and the barium swallow image show a bird beak sign which indicates achalasia cardia. To confirm the diagnosis, Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry should be performed. Manometry is the IOC for achalasia cardia and other motility disorders.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. UGIE + contrast enhanced CT: While useful for structural evaluation, it does not specifically assess esophageal motility.
  • • Option A. UGIE + contrast enhanced CT:
  • • Option B. UGIE + PET: Typically used for oncological assessments, not directly useful for diagnosing motility disorders.
  • • Option B. UGIE + PET:
  • • Option C. UGIE + 24-hour pH monitoring: Used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not directly relevant for achalasia unless GERD is also suspected.
  • • Option C. UGIE + 24-hour pH monitoring:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B Susceptibility weighted image

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI ) is an MRI sequence which is sensitive to compounds that can distort the local magnetic field.
  • • Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI
  • • Type of Gradient echo sequence / T2* sequence
  • • Black dots s/o hemorrhage known as blooming
  • • Sequence of choice for DAI (diffuse axonal injury)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Proton density image: Typically used to provide good anatomical detail and contrast of soft tissues, not specifically sensitive to magnetic susceptibilities.
  • • Option A. Proton density image:
  • • Option C. Gradient echo image: While SWI uses gradient echo sequences, it specifically exploits phase data and magnitude data to enhance the visibility of substances affecting magnetic susceptibility.
  • • Option C. Gradient echo image:
  • • Option D. Inversion recovery image: This MRI technique is used to suppress or enhance certain tissue types based on their relaxation properties, which is not indicative of the contrast seen in this image.
  • • Option D. Inversion recovery image:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is particularly useful in detecting and differentiating substances in the brain that affect magnetic susceptibility, such as iron and blood, making it an excellent choice for identifying microhemorrhages and assessing diffuse axonal injury.

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance . It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter . It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.
  • • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance . It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter .
  • • adder head sign/ cobra head
  • • appearance
  • • cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter
  • • It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Horse shoe kidney: Characterized by a "hand-shake" or "flower vase" sign due to the fusion of the kidneys across the midline, typically seen in the lower lumbar region. This appearance does not match the image shown.
  • • Option B. Horse shoe kidney:
  • • Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Often causes medial deviation of the ureters or a "silent kidney" if severe obstruction occurs. Not relevant to the observed sign.
  • • Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis:
  • • Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Affects male infants primarily and involves obstruction within the posterior urethra, leading to bladder and kidney changes. It does not cause the "cobra head" appearance seen here.
  • • Option D. Posterior urethral valve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ureterocele should be suspected when an IVP reveals a "cobra head" sign, representing cystic dilation of the distal ureter. This condition can affect urinary drainage and lead to complications, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A child presents with history of acute dysphagia. CXR is shown below. What is the next best step? (AIIMS 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Reassure and to check whether passed in stools

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Remove endoscopically

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given CXR shows a foreign body in the esophagus which is likely to be a button battery as seen by the double margins.
  • • In profile/ en face: Foreign body is in the esophagus
  • • The next step should be to endoscopically removing those batteries as they lead to tissue necrosis by liquefactive necrosis.
  • • Patient’s oral intake should be prohibited until the location of the foreign body is confirmed. Never induce vomiting in these patients as it can again lodge back in the esophagus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy: Bronchoscopy is not suitable as the foreign body is located in the esophagus, not the airways.
  • • Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy:
  • • Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools: This approach is inappropriate due to the urgent risk of tissue damage from the battery; immediate removal is necessary.
  • • Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools:
  • • Option D. Induce vomiting: Inducing vomiting is contraindicated as it can cause further esophageal injury or lead to re-lodgement of the battery in the esophagus.
  • • Option D. Induce vomiting:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected ingestion of button batteries as seen on CXR, urgent endoscopic removal is critical to prevent tissue damage and potential complications. Vomiting should never be induced in these situations as it can exacerbate the problem.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above CT image showing a calcified lesion in the liver with a lamellar wall which indicates hydatid disease.
  • • Caused by Echinococcus granulosus → Humans – accidental host
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Typically presents as a solid tumor with irregular borders and might show vascular invasion or enhancement after contrast administration, not typically calcified.
  • • Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma:
  • • Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia: Refers to a benign liver lesion that generally does not demonstrate the clear, calcified, and layered appearance of a hydatid cyst.
  • • Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia:
  • • Option C. Liver abscess: Would more likely present as a fluid-filled lesion with possible air-fluid levels and peripheral enhancement after contrast, not the lamellar calcification seen here.
  • • Option C. Liver abscess:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydatid cysts in the liver are recognized on CT scans by their calcified, lamellar structure and are an important differential when considering cystic liver lesions, particularly in regions where Echinococcus is endemic.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C Pneumothorax

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space.
  • • DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax
  • • DIAGNOSIS:
  • • MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral
  • • MEDIASTINAL SHIFT:
  • • MOST SENSITIVE IX : CT scan
  • • MOST SENSITIVE IX
  • • MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray
  • • MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Often presents with sudden onset dyspnea and may show signs of right heart strain on imaging, but it does not directly cause the visible signs of air in the pleural cavity as seen in pneumothorax.
  • • Option A. Pulmonary embolism:
  • • Option B. Hydropneumothorax: This would be indicated by both air and fluid levels within the pleural space, which are not visible in this X-ray.
  • • Option B. Hydropneumothorax:
  • • Option D. Aortic dissection: Would potentially show mediastinal widening or other structural abnormalities, which are not depicted in this image.
  • • Option D. Aortic dissection:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumothorax is identified by the visible presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, and is commonly associated with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea, especially in patients with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Superior vena cava

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.
  • • 1. Football sign:
  • • 2. Rat tail sign: Typically seen in carcinoma of the esophagus, this sign describes the tapering of the esophageal lumen due to the tumor, resembling a rat’s tail. .
  • • 2. Rat tail sign:
  • • 3. String sign: Found in CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis), it refers to the appearance of a narrowed, elongated channel through the pylorus.
  • • 3. String sign:
  • • 4. Inverted umbrella sign: This is seen in cases of TB (tuberculosis), particularly referring to the appearance of a contracted cecum and narrow ileocecal junction
  • • 4. Inverted umbrella sign:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Mt. Fuji sign is seen in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pneumocephalus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mt. Fuji sign is indicative of tension pneumocephalus and is characterized by the peaking of the frontal lobes due to intracranial air pressure.

questions.text: Below is an image of an MRCP scan. Which of the following options is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Choledocholithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choledocholithiasis is diagnosed primarily through imaging like MRCP, which reveals stones within the common bile duct as distinct circular filling defects. This condition is a significant cause of biliary obstruction and requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as severe biliary colic and obstructive jaundice.

questions.text: Identify the mediastinal mass shown in the image. The measured Hounsfield unit in the mass revealed -70 HU. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Teratoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negative Hounsfield Unit values (between -10 to -100) indicate the presence of fat within a lesion, suggesting that the mass could be a teratoma, especially when accompanied by calcifications.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Putty kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Putty kidney is an advanced renal pathology often resulting from chronic infections such as tuberculosis, leading to extensive calcification and renal dysfunction. This condition is distinguishable on imaging by its irregular, extensive calcifications throughout the kidney, associated with clinical symptoms like abdominal pain and sterile pyuria.

questions.text: Identify this sign on USG: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the "Seashore sign" on M-mode ultrasound, which is used primarily to evaluate for lung sliding. The seashore sign is characterized by a sandy or granular pattern in the lower half of the M-mode display, beneath the pleural line. This pattern is caused by the motion of the lung relative to the pleura during breathing. It is a normal finding, indicating that the lung is sliding smoothly against the parietal pleura, which helps rule out conditions like pneumothorax in the area scanned.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the "barcode sign," it appears as parallel lines in M-mode and is associated with the absence of lung sliding, often seen in cases of pneumothorax.
  • • Option B. Stratosphere sign:
  • • Option C. Lung point sign: This is seen in lung ultrasound as the point at which the normal seashore sign of lung sliding transitions to the stratosphere sign in cases of pneumothorax. It is specific for pneumothorax but not depicted in this ultrasound image.
  • • Option C. Lung point sign:
  • • Option D. Sinusoidal sign: Typically refers to a waveform pattern seen in various types of medical imaging and monitoring, not relevant to the depiction of lung sliding on ultrasound.
  • • Option D. Sinusoidal sign:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lung sliding- seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between pleural layer. Seashore sign- M mode counterpart of lung sliding. Motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes grainy appearance in M-mode, stimulating sand in a seashore.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with hypertension and chest pain. A chest radiograph was taken as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and the chest X-ray depicting the figure of 3 sign are suggestive of coarctation of aorta to be the cause of hypertension in this patient.
  • • figure of 3 sign
  • • are suggestive of coarctation of aorta
  • • Typical C/F: Brachio-femoral delay – Upper limb pulsations/BP is high; Lower limb pulsation/BP is feeble.
  • • Typical C/F:
  • • Lower limb pulsation/BP is feeble.
  • • Radiological investigation:
  • • Radiological investigation:
  • • Figure of 3 signs on CXR Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign
  • • Figure of 3 signs on CXR
  • • Figure of 3
  • • Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign
  • • Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Essential hypertension: More common in older adults and usually doesn't show specific findings on a chest X-ray.
  • • Option B. Essential hypertension:
  • • Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Associated with high calcium levels and bone resorption signs, not directly causing visible changes on a chest X-ray linked with hypertension.
  • • Option C. Hyperparathyroidism:
  • • Option D. Takayasu arteritis: A vasculitis that might show narrowing or dilation of the aorta or its branches, but it typically affects younger women and would likely show different patterns on imaging.
  • • Option D. Takayasu arteritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta can be identified on a chest X-ray by the "figure of 3" sign, and it should be suspected in young patients presenting with hypertension and signs of upper body hypertension contrasted with lower limb hypotension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Extradural Hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image demonstrates a right-sided hyperdense lesion, characteristic of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). Features supporting this diagnosis include:
  • • Shape and Location: The lesion exhibits a biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, typically not crossing sutures, localized at the pterion which is a common site for EDH due to its proximity to the middle meningeal artery (MMA).
  • • Shape and Location:
  • • Type of Trauma : Associated with high-energy trauma such as a road traffic accident, often causing arterial bleeding, specifically from the MMA.
  • • Type of Trauma
  • • Lucid Interval: Patients may experience a lucid interval where symptoms improve temporarily before deteriorating, due to the building pressure from the accumulating blood.
  • • Lucid Interval:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH): Typically appears as a crescentic or "banana-shaped" collection that can cross sutures but not midline. It arises from bridging veins, often due to lower-energy trauma.
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH):
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Usually presents as diffuse or patchy areas of increased density in the subarachnoid spaces, not shown in the image.
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Would be visualized within the ventricular system, which is not evident here.
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the lesion seen in a patient with chronic smoking history and weight loss. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cannon ball appearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In patients with a significant history of smoking and systemic symptoms like weight loss, the appearance of multiple rounded opacities on chest X-ray should prompt consideration of metastatic disease.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. PET CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A PET CT scan is crucial for the integrated assessment of anatomical and metabolic information, particularly useful in oncology for identifying and tracking the behavior of tumors based on their glucose metabolism, as visualized through radiotracer uptake.
